column1: '''Luvailin''' or '''Shadowmere''' was a mere in [[Eldamar]] under the shadow of [[Oiolossë]].<ref name=UI>{{HM|UI}}
Shadowmere is mentioned  in [[Bilbo Baggins|Bilbo's]]  [[Song of Eärendil]]<ref>{{FR|II1}}</ref> in [[Rivendell]]:
As the mere reflected the lights of the city of Tirion
column2: "it must have lain in or near to" the valley of [[Calacirya]].<ref>{{webcite|author=Mark Fisher|articleurl=http://www.glyphweb.com/arda/s/shadowmere.html|articlename=Shadowmere|dated=8 November 2008|website=EoA|accessed=22 November 2013}}</ref>

column1: ''Luvailin'' appears only in the ''[[Unfinished index]]''. The name ''Shadowmere'' is said to be its "translation".<ref name=UI/> Though Tolkien did not provide an explanation of the latter
column2: [[Tolkien fandom|fans]] have speculated that ''Luvailin'' seems to contain the elements ''luv-'' *"shadow-" (seemingly from √LUM
column13: p. 77).</ref> and that it is unclear if the name is supposed to be [[Quenya]] or [[Sindarin]].<ref>{{webcite|author=|articleurl=http://www.lotrplaza.com/showthread.php?76445-Shadowmere-a-quot-translation-quot-of-Luvailin|articlename=Shadowmere

column1: In an early version of [[Galadriel's Song of Eldamar]]
''And by the strand of Tirion there grew a golden Tree.
''Beneath the stars of Ever eve in Eldamar it shone
''In Eldamar beside the walls of Elven Tirion.
''But far away and far away beyond the '''Shadow-meres'''''

A different version of the second line above was: ''Beneath the Hill of Ilmarin lies Aelinuial''.<ref group=note>The name ''[[Aelin-uial]]'' appears in ''[[The Silmarillion]]'' as a name for the Meres of Twilight in [[Beleriand]].</ref><ref>{{TI|XIV}}
